content.value: Environmental policy instruments have the potential to be applied to a wide range of environmental and natural resource issues, with the objective to provide a permanent incentive to environmentally harmful activities through pollution abatement, technical innovation, and product substitution. Policy instruments include taxes and fees (or charges) including emission,
Payments on the emission of pollutants into air or water or onto or into soil and on the generation of noise.
Payments for the costs of collective treatment of effluent or waste.
Levied on products that are harmful to the environment when used in production processes, consumed or disposed of.

subsidies to provide financial support of environmental goods and services; tradeable permits designed to reach an overall pollution ceiling with maximum efficiency, or to encourage the efficient use of natural resources; and deposit refund systems paid on the return of potentially polluting products or their residuals. Other types of economic instruments include enforcement incentives, fines, non-compliance fees, administrative charges, performance bonds, and damage compensation.

Environmental policy instruments usually operate as part of a “mix” of instruments, whereby several instruments are often applied to the same environmental problem. Combining several instruments can enhance the environmental effectiveness and economic efficiency of both by explicitly considering the way in which different instruments interact. Policy instruments should be designed in accordance with national circumstances and sectors’ pricing and fiscal structures in order to facilitate the integration of environmental policy with other policies. Contextual factors to be considered carefully include environmental conditions, economic situations and fiscal structures in the countries involved, as well as institutional capacity, the feasibility of monitoring and evaluation, the responsiveness of the industries concerned and the potential for technical innovation,

This section shows selected policy instruments based on data available for most LAC countries. Itdoes not provide a complete overview of countries’ policy mixes to achieve their environment-related objectives. Interpretation should consider the country specific context.

While deploying a tailored combination of market-based and non-market-based policy instruments is useful to achieve an effective policy mix,  the diverse approaches used difficult  the assessment and comparability of policy instruments over time and across countries. Notwithstanding these differences. countries tend to focus their efforts on two cross‑cutting action areas:

Enabling action by establishing targets, integrated and multi-level governance, and enabling information. Targets provide key short- and long-term signals to citizens and firms about a government’s ambition. Short-term and long-term targets are implemented through policy packages that tackle different externalities on the path to achieve the targets.
Meeting objectives through policy packages, including a diverse set of instruments
such as regulatory or information instruments are needed to support the adoption of technologies that are already cost competitive with other more environmentally harmful alternatives.
, such as carbon pricing, change behaviour through financial means.
enable the development of new, and reduce the costs of advanced, technologies that are needed to achieve the targets in the coming decades.

The search for better environment-economy-equity integration has underlain many of the recent developments in the environmental policy sphere. Effective and efficient policy integration implies the institutionalisation of solid procedures for setting objectives, for identifying and analysing available options, for consulting with stakeholders, and for carrying out regular ex post analysis of both policy objectives and instruments.

The LAC region faces the challenge of financing the green transition under a tight fiscal space. A 2.5°C global warming scenario could cost the region between 1.5% and 5.0% of its GDP by 2050. Since the cost of inaction is high, countries must develop environmentally sustainable fiscal policies. These include infrastructure plans with adaptation and mitigation goals. These policies also entail focusing on more and better spending on clean energy and energy efficiency, and on phasing‑out fossil fuel subsidies and support measures, particularly to the most affluent population (OECD et al., 2022).
In addition, the region needs to mobilise new ways to generate additional revenues, such as environmentally‑related taxes, emissions trading systems (ETS) and scaling up debt tools.

Tax revenues remain low in LAC. In 2020, the average tax‑to‑GDP ratio was 21.9% of GDP compared to 33.5% in the OECD. As a result, the gap between the LAC and OECD tax‑to‑GDP ratios widened to 11.6% of GDP in 2020 from 10.7% in 2019. The gap is mainly explained by the region’s low revenues from income taxes and social security contributions relative to the OECD average. The combined share of taxes on income and profits (especially personal income taxes) and social security contributions was much lower in the LAC region than in the OECD (44.1% versus 60.0% in 2019, on average) (OECD et al., 2022).

On average in LAC, environment‑related tax revenues amounted to only 1% of GDP in 2020, just half of the estimated OECD average of 2% of GDP. Scaling up tools of debt, such as green, social, sustainable and sustainability‑Linked (GSSS) bonds, debt‑for‑nature swaps, catastrophe bonds, and natural disaster clauses, can also help raise additional revenues to ensure flows of resources target climate action. The GSSS market reached an accumulated USD 73 billion from 2014 to September 2021, of which green bond issuance accounted for USD 31 billion alone followed by social with USD 17 billion (OECD et al., 2022).

content.value: The indicators on environmentally related taxes should not be used to assess the “environmental friendliness” of the tax systems. For such analysis, additional information, describing the economic and taxation structure of each country, is required. Moreover, a number of environmentally related taxes can have important environmental impacts even if they raise little (or no) revenue. In addition, revenue from fees and charges, and from royalties related to resource management, is not included.

Comparisons of ERTRs provide a useful starting point for analysing the impact of environmental taxation, however, comparing only the levels of revenue does not provide the full picture of a country’s environmental policy, as it does not provide information on the levels of tax rates or the exemptions applied. Other parts of the OECD PINE database, including information on tax rates and exemptions, allows deeper assessment of the environmental impacts of these taxes. In addition, governments may choose to implement environmental policy using a range of other instruments, including fees and charges, expenditures (both direct and subsidies) and regulation, some of which are also detailed in the PINE database (see
for information on the use of alternative instruments in countries).

toc.value: Environment at a Glance Indicators: Latin America and Caribbean (LAC) provides interactive on-line access to the latest comparable LAC-country data on the environment. The tool helps users evaluate environmental performance in the region’s countries and track their course towards sustainable development. This web version allows users to play with the data, dive into the analysis and download the webbook. The indicators provide key messages on major environmental trends in areas such as climate change, biodiversity, and selected policy responses to these issues. They will be progressively extended to cover other areas such as water resources, air quality, circular economy, and ocean resources as more information becomes available.
